table-wrap.anchoringText: Coreflood history match result is given in Figure 3. Overall the match result was satisfactory, especially in matching of oil bank breakthrough and final cumulative oil recovery (red line). Parameter used in history matching are given on Table 1. Notethat critical capillary number usedfor history match is based on calculated values from coreflood data. Comparison between calculated and simulated capillary number is given in Figure 4. It can be seen that simulated capillary number have close agreement with calculated data from coreflood. This should ensure that the simulation gave proper capillary desaturation curve as observed in coreflood result. Matched parameter is then employed in available rock curves in field reservoir model for forecast.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Coreflood Matching Parameter

table-wrap.anchoringText: Values used for each parameter in sensitivity analysis is given on Table 2. Lower surfactant adsorption values play significant role in accelerating oil bank breakthrough time however it is not the most significant parameter in affecting cumulative oil production. Lower critical capillary number also lead to faster oil bank breakthrough and higher cumulative oil recovered. Higher residual oil reduction gave faster oil bank breakthrough time and higher recovery. Surprisingly, higher permeability values used in permeability streak does not correspond to faster and higher oil recovery from surfactant flood. The significance of each parameter is represented in tornadoplotsas shown in Figure 10and Figure 11. The sensitivity analysis exercised provide guidance on adjusting the parameters for history match.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Parameter Value in Sensitivity Analysis
